name: NCD - Deep Brain Stimulation for Essential Tremor and Parkinson’s Disease
description: National Coverage Determination for unilateral or bilateral deep brain stimulation (DBS) for the treatment of essential tremor (ET), Parkinsonian tremor, and Parkinson's disease (PD), specifying device, patient, provider, and facility eligibility criteria, as well as exclusions and contraindications.

restrictions.condition: DBS device is Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved
DBS device used in accordance with FDA approved protocols governing Category B Investigational Device Exemption (IDE) DBS clinical trials
For thalamic VIM DBS: Diagnosis of Essential Tremor (ET) based on postural or kinetic tremors of hand(s) without other neurologic signs
For thalamic VIM DBS: Diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson's Disease (PD) with presence of at least 2 cardinal PD features (tremor, rigidity or bradykinesia) and of a tremor-dominant form
For thalamic VIM DBS: Marked disabling tremor of at least level 3 or 4 on the Fahn-Tolosa-Marin Clinical Tremor Rating Scale (or equivalent scale) in the extremity intended for treatment
For thalamic VIM DBS: Tremor causing significant limitation in daily activities
For thalamic VIM DBS: Disabling tremor persists despite optimal medical therapy
For thalamic VIM DBS: Patient's willingness and ability to cooperate during conscious operative procedure, post-surgical evaluations, and adjustments of medications and stimulator settings
For STN or GPi DBS: Diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease (PD) based on the presence of at least 2 cardinal PD features (tremor, rigidity or bradykinesia)
For STN or GPi DBS: Advanced idiopathic Parkinson's Disease (PD) as determined by Hoehn and Yahr stage or Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) part III motor subscale
For STN or GPi DBS: Patient is L-dopa responsive with clearly defined 'on' periods
For STN or GPi DBS: Persistent disabling Parkinson's symptoms or drug side effects (e.g., dyskinesias, motor fluctuations, or disabling 'off' periods) despite optimal medical therapy
For STN or GPi DBS: Patient's willingness and ability to cooperate during conscious operative procedure, post-surgical evaluations, and adjustments of medications and stimulator settings
Not excluded due to non-idiopathic Parkinson's disease or 'Parkinson's Plus' syndromes
Not excluded due to cognitive impairment that would be worsened by or interfere with DBS benefit
Not excluded due to dementia that would be worsened by or interfere with DBS benefit
Not excluded due to depression that would be worsened by or interfere with DBS benefit
Not excluded due to current psychosis
Not excluded due to alcohol abuse
Not excluded due to other drug abuse
Not excluded due to structural lesions (e.g., basal ganglionic stroke, tumor, vascular malformation) as etiology of the movement disorder
Not excluded due to previous movement disorder surgery within the affected basal ganglion
Not excluded due to significant medical, surgical, neurologic, or orthopedic co-morbidities contraindicating DBS surgery or stimulation
Patients who undergo DBS implantation should not be exposed to diathermy
Patients who undergo DBS implantation should not be exposed to any type of MRI
DBS procedure should be performed with extreme caution in patients with cardiac pacemakers
DBS procedure should be performed with extreme caution in patients with other electronically controlled implants
Neurosurgeon must be properly trained in the Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) procedure
Neurosurgeon must have experience with the surgical management of movement disorders, including DBS therapy
Neurosurgeon must have experience performing stereotactic neurosurgical procedures
Operative teams must have training and experience with DBS systems
Physicians specializing in movement disorders must be involved in patient selection and post-procedure care for DBS
Hospital medical centers must have brain imaging equipment (MRI and/or CT) for pre-operative stereotactic localization and targeting of surgical sites
Hospital medical centers must have operating rooms with all necessary equipment for stereotactic surgery
Hospital medical centers must have support services necessary for patient care during and after DBS procedure, including potential complications
